Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Climate change, sustainable environment and livable cities
Outcome: 3.1 By 2025, all relevant actors take measures to accelerate climate action, to promote responsible production and consumption, to improve the management of risks and threats to people, to ensure sustainable management of the environment and natural resources in urban and ecosystem hinterlands.
Output: Output 3.1.2 Nature-based integrated solutions adopted by public institutions, CSOs and private sector, and scaled up for sustainable management of biodiversity and natural resources and ecosystems at sector, urban and rural context
Sub-Output: 3.1.2.1 Territorial Diagnostic Analysis of the Bodrum city and urban area to determine the most appropriate Nature-based Solutions and green infrastructure to include in urban planning policy to promote climate change adaptation, sustainable tourism and ecosystem management.
Implementation partners: Bodrum Municipality
SDG Targets: 11.1 By 2030, ensure access for all to adequate, safe and affordable housing and basic services and upgrade slums.,11.5 By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.,11.6 By 2030, reduce the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities, including by paying special attention to air quality and municipal and other waste management.,11.a Support positive economic, social and environmental links between urban, peri-urban and rural areas by strengthening national and regional development planning.,11.b By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.,12.2 By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.,12.5 By 2030, substantially reduce waste generation through prevention, reduction, recycling and reuse.,15.9 By 2020, integrate ecosystem and biodiversity values into national and local planning, development processes, poverty reduction strategies and accounts.,15.a Mobilize and significantly increase financial resources from all sources to conserve and sustainable use biodiversity and ecosystems.
SDG Goals: 11 Sustainable Cities and Communities, 12 Responsible Consumption and Production, 15 Life on Land

Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: Community Recovery interventions and nexus approaches in key sectors address displacement and strengthen individual and community resilience
Output: Mine Action and Debris Removal
Sub-Output: Enhanced Mine Action management in Ukraine
Contributing partners: Agence Espagnole de Coopération pour le Développement, Government of Belgium, Government of Croatia, Government of Denmark, Government of France, Government of Luxembourg, Government of Malta, Government of New Zealand, Government of Sweden, Government of the Netherlands, Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, United Kingdom Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office
Implementation partners: United Nations Mine Action Service
SDG Targets: 16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: Through enhanced demining capacity of Mine Action government institutions (equipment for pyrotechnic teams), in particular the State Emergency Service of Ukraine (SESU), the Project contributed to a safe environment for both internally displaced people (IDPs) and those who did not leave their place of origin in conflict-affected areas. By clearing de-occupied territories contaminated by explosive remnants of war, demining government institutions remove EO-related hazards from such areas, and the risk of population accidental injuries or deaths is being significantly reduced. It allowed conflict-affected people to feel safe outside the home and to move about their communities without fear of stepping on or encountering explosive devices.
2024 Narrative: Key accomplishments include empowering responders, advancing inclusive growth, supporting victim assistance, and championing Ukrainian innovation. These efforts contributed to 20 activities under the National Mine Action Strategy for 2024–2033, with UNDP's technical expertise playing a significant role.The provision of equipment to 202 State Emergency Service of Ukraine (SESU) demining teams boosted the operational capacity of national mine action efforts. MAP deployed 7 Non-Technical Survey (NTS) teams to survey 11.7 million m² of war-affected land, releasing 3.91 million m², benefitting 1,369 individuals in Chernihiv and Kharkiv oblasts, in communities with a population of 73,092.To enhance Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) capabilities, 16 National Police of Ukraine (NPU) specialists received training on Hook and Line (HL) systems. Additionally, 8 NPU and 2 SESU EOD specialists completed a joint HL training of trainers course. MAP also conducted underwater EOD training for 6 specialists with Lithuanian Anti-Terrorist Operations Unit 'ARAS.'Animal detection systems (ADS) progressed with the introduction of Technical Survey Dog (TSD) methodology in Ukraine. 8 women dog handlers were trained, deploying 12 TSDs for rapid land release. The second phase of unmanned technologies testing in humanitarian demining, focusing on sensors, drones, and AI to detect explosives, was completed with 7 Ukrainian companies involved. This testing will contribute to developing a unified standard for using unmanned technologies.UNDP’s report on innovative financing proposed mechanisms like Sustainability-Linked Bonds and Outcome-Based Public-Private Partnerships to address a $34.6 billion funding gap and align mine action with agriculture and renewable energy.A strengthened Information Management System for Mine Action (IMSMA) was established, training 58 Information Management Officers (IMOs), including 10 veterans with disabilities, in mapping, spatial analysis, and geospatial data management. This improved operational efficiency and informed decision-making for key Ukrainian institutions. Additionally, MAP is developing a debris removal system tailored for SESU, focusing on monitoring casualties from explosive remnants of war (ERW). A second training session for 12 veterans on mechanical demining provided practical knowledge on equipment, and 4 veterans secured jobs in humanitarian demining.MAP has made incremental progress in mainstreaming disability inclusiveness and advancing the UNDP Model of victim assistance in Ukraine. Trainings have strengthened the EO victim assistance system at both national and local levels. These include:•	Workshops on "National Standards for Medical Support to Demining Operations," contributing to recommendations for national standards.•	15 healthcare professionals trained in advanced rehabilitation techniques for EO victims in Denmark.•	68 health professionals trained in Post-Amputation Mobility Aid (PPAM) for EO victims.•	415 professionals from NGOs, the Ministry of Social Policy (MoSP), and State Employment Services (SES) received training on social support services for EO victims and PWDs.•	167 local authorities and NGOs from Kharkiv, Kherson, Mykolaiv, Kyiv, and Chernihiv oblasts participated in workshops to build local support networks for EO victims.•	92 local authorities from Kharkiv, Kherson, and Mykolaiv participated in a workshop on the new National Mine Action Strategy.•	24 NPU participants enhanced skills in service provision for people with impairments, including EO survivors, considering PWD protection and human rights in policing.•	25 psychologists from SESU received training on mental health and psychosocial support for war-affected populations, including EO victims.•	101 specialists trained in trauma-informed communication and service provision.•	81 social workers trained to provide quality social services to vulnerable communities, including EO victims.MAP also organized the TECH4Life Congress, showcasing innovative assistive technology, with over 350 in-person and 3,500 online participants.To ensure knowledge sharing in global forums, MAP secured the participation of 3 NMAA official, a representative from the MoEC, and a veteran who had completed IM training, in the Fifth Review Conference of the Anti-Personnel Mine Ban Convention (APMBC) on a Mine-Free World, held in Siem Reap, Cambodia. UNDP presented on two panels, including Victim Assistance and innovation in mine action.

2023 Narrative: The Project contributed to the transition from the Mine Action Subcluster (MASC) to the Mine Action Area of Responsibility (MA AoR). MA AoR offers a platform to MA humanitarian operators to coordinate their activities and offer a platform for exchange of the experience in the sphere.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Prosperity and Planet - Inclusive Economic Growth and Environmental Sustainability
Outcome: Outcome 3.1: By 2025, all people in Kazakhstan, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, resilient, and sustainable economic development with improved productive capacities, skills and equal opportunities for sustainable and decent jobs, livelihoods, and businesses.
Output: Output 3.1.3: Increased capacities of MMSEs and enterpenuers to create a conducive environment, to better integrate into the value chains, develop innovative approaches for enterpeneurial activities, and create decent job opportunities
Sub-Output: Leveraging Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) to achieve net-zero emissions and climate-resilient development, in response to the climate emergency
Description: The Project aims to introduce new climate smart technologies that can be scaled up on most of the farms, in the field of renewable energy, digitalization for water use, and proper drought control for small- and medium-size agriculture enterprises facing both COVID-19 and climate crises at the same time. In addition, the Project will improve the existing meteorological surveillance system, which will increase the resilience to droughts. Capacity building activities envisages gender perspective by empowering emerging women scholars, practitioners and women-led SMEs in climate smart mechanization sector in partnership with UNDP STEM4All platform.
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,7.2 By 2030, increase substantially the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix.
SDG Goals: 5 Gender Equality, 7 Affordable and Clean Energy
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: the project focused on water-saving technologies and drought-resistant crops to ensure efficient water resource usage. The installation of water-saving equipment on farms contributed to water conservation and increased crop areas. The project aimed to scale up the adoption of low-carbon technologies and approaches in the agricultural sector. This was achieved through capacity-building programs designed to empower farmers with the knowledge and skills necessary to implement sustainable practices. Additionally, the project focused on developing five standardized solutions specifically tailored to the agricultural sector. It also prioritized gender perspective and empowering women in the climate-smart mechanization sector through collaboration with the UNDP STEM4All platform. Monitoring and knowledge on drought forecasting and mitigation were improved and the understanding of climate-related vulnerability to drought advanced. Demonstrated climate-smart agriculture technologies for renewable energy, and water management allowed to increase resilience of the farmers on the ground.The project systematically approached the issue of resilience of the agricultural sector to climate change by improving the processing capacity of the meteorological surveillance system and expert capacity on forecasting and response to mitigate the impact of droughts in Kazakhstan.The project envisaged raising public awareness about climate change through various means. This included educational trainings conducted for farmers across Kazakhstan, emphasizing the significance of alternative energy sources in combating climate change.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Good governance and quality of judiciary services
Outcome: 4.2 By 2025, the effectiveness of the international protection and migration management system is improved.
Output: Output 4.2.1. National/local institutions are supported to ensure that protection-sensitive access to international protection and management of entry, stay and exit pathways are improved in line with the LFIP
Sub-Output: 4.2.1.19 Awareness raising on mine action among the communities
Implementation partners: National Mine Action Center (TURMAC)
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,16.1 Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Under the Anti-Personnel Mine Ban Convention, Turkey has committed itself to destroy all landmines and improve its institutional capacity towards mine action with the primary goal of humanitarian dimension and has been fulfilling the requirements of the agreement by clearing the mines and strengthens its border security with humanitarian and modern systems. UNDP managed the two phases of the project, and in Phase I and Phase II, approximately 45,600 anti-personnel mines were destroyed and 4.7 million m2 of land along a 34 km stretch of the border was released. 
Being the only ongoing project in integrated border management and the largest scale project of UNDP CO, Demining Phase 3 started in January 2021 and following results were achieved by the end of 2021:
Component 1: Clearance of up to 4.2 million m² of land
Demining Contractor and Quality Management Service Provider procurement processes were completed, and demining operations started in June 2021. 346,854 sqm out of 883.000 (25% of 3.6m sqm) has been manually cleared and 18444 mines were found and removed. These cleared areas are to be handed over to TURMAC after completion of verification. 
Component 2: Capacity building activities for TURMAC
Training programs have been designed in coordination with TURMAC to cover Technical Survey GICHD online Training Course, QM ISO 9000/9001 Lead Auditor Training Turkish Commercial Organisation and a follow up GICHD Quality Management Training Course, MDD Training/Accreditation Procedures Agreed Training Program with TURMAC, IMSMA Core User Training GICHD follow up visit to TURMAC and EORE GICHD online Training Course. 
ISO9001 training was delivered to 8 key experts of TURMAC and other trainings will be delivered in 2022.
Component 3: Mine Risk Education
Mine Risk Education was originally planned to be conducted after an Impact Assessment Base Line Study, which is under discussion with the EUD for replacement with a mid-term evaluation due to lack of experts to conduct such and Impact Assessment. 14 MRE sessions are planned to be conducted in 2022 after approval of the Impact Assessment by the EUD. 
On the other hand, education and awareness raising materials were produced for the MRE sessions to be delivered by the Gendarmerie in 900 villages. 
Component 4: Non-Technical Survey
Procurement process for the NTS Contractor was completed and operations started in June 2021. On-site surveys of 955 minefields were completed and NTS reports of 200 hazardous areas were approved by TURMAC.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Democratic Governance
Outcome: Outcome 3.1 - Environmental Sustainability
Output: Output 3.1.1 - Climate change and environment targets integrated into national policies, strategies and planning.
Sub-Output: 3.1.1.17 - Revision of Nationaly Determined Contribution (NDC)
Description:
With its first NDC submitted in 2015, Montenegro obliged to decrease its GHG emissions by 30%, compared to 1990. Five years from the Paris Agrement all signatory parties, including Montenegro, are obliged to set new, preferably more ambitious targets. Revision of NDC will include all relevant sectors and gasses, and should be submitted to the UNFCCC before COP 26 (to be held in November 2020).
As COP 26 was postponed for 2021 due to Covid 19, submission of NDC is also postponed for 2021.
Implementation partners: MSDT
SDG Targets: 13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) was revised, adopted by the Government and enhanced NDC was submitted to UNFCCC Secretariat in June 2021.  	

Nacionalno utvrdjeni doprinos (NDC) je revidovan, usvojen od strane vlade i podnesen Sekretarijatu UNFCCC u junu 2021.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Climate action, natural resources and disaster risk management
Outcome: Outcome 3: Healthy Environment
Output: Output 3.1 Low-emissions development and climate change resilience
Sub-Output: Derisking Roadmap and Financing Strategy for the enhanced Nationally Determined Contributions developed
Description: Development of analyses and recommendations that will support the implementation of the  enhanced NDCs
Contributing partners: The Global Environment Facility, United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning, North Macedonia Ministry of Finance
SDG Targets: 13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: The Macedonian enhanced Nationally Determined Contributions on Climate change (eNDC), developed with UNDP’s support, sets a national goal to achieve 51% reduction of GHG emissions by 2030 compared to 1990 emissions thus setting the stage for low carbon development of the country. The eNDC was accompanied by a Roadmap for Implementation and a Strategy for Financing of the Macedonian enhanced NDC. Both documents provide for addressing the biggest challenge and highest priority posed for the eNDC implementation - decoupling energy-related emissions from GDP growth. Also, the Policy and financial de-risking for all enhanced eNDC sectors and the Roadmap for introduction of carbon tax in the country are further enhancing the enabling environment for implementation of the measures and actions definite in the enhanced NDC. The Climate Budget Tagging methodology commenced by UNDP shall help to integrate climate change into the national public financial management system. The Ministry of Finance has already incorporated the climate tagging in relevant draft law.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote inclusive and gender transformative approaches to climate action, disaster risk management and environmental protection to conserve natural resources and leverage ecosystem benefits for sustainable human development (CLIMATE, ENERGY, DRM AND BIODIVERSITY)

Description: National long-term strategy for carbon neutrality and medium-term people-centered mitigation policies, in accordance with the Nationally Determined Contributions, including e-mobility, waste management and energy, with gender-sensitive action framework are developed
Contributing partners: Core Funding, German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Civil Society Organizations, Kyrgyz Ministry of Agriculture, Kyrgyz Ministry of Culture, Information, Sports and Youth Policy, Kyrgyz Ministry of Economy and Commerce, Kyrgyz Ministry of Education and Science, Kyrgyz Ministry of Emergency Situations, Kyrgyz Ministry of Energy, Kyrgyz Ministry of Finance, Kyrgyz Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Kyrgyz Ministry of Health, Kyrgyz Ministry of Labour, Social Security and Migration, Kyrgyz Ministry of Natural Resources, Ecology and Technical Supervision, Kyrgyz National Statistical Committee, Kyrgyz Parliament, Kyrgyz President Administration, Kyrgyz Private Sector
SDG Targets: 5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,5.c Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.,7.1 By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.,7.2 By 2030, increase substantially the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix.,7.a By 2030, enhance international cooperation to facilitate access to clean energy research and technology, including renewable energy, energy efficiency and advanced and cleaner fossil-fuel technology, and promote investment in energy infrastructure and clean energy technology.,8.4 Improve progressively, through 2030, global resource efficiency in consumption and production and endeavour to decouple economic growth from environmental degradation, in accordance with the 10-year framework of programmes on sustainable consumption and production, with developed countries taking the lead.,11.6 By 2030, reduce the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities, including by paying special attention to air quality and municipal and other waste management.,12.2 By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.,13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.,17.14 Enhance policy coherence for sustainable development.

QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Normative Support, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, Women & Girls, Children , Persons With Disabilities, Migrants
2023 Narrative: The UNDP's Global Climate Promise has driven transformative change in the country's climate approach, it fortified NDCs, and strategically charted pathways for carbon neutrality by 2050 Long-term Strategy, aligning with adaptation plans. The NDC implementation plan prioritized gender-sensitive measures in adaptation and mitigation. The UNDP notably boosted the Energy Efficiency Program, enhancing energy conservation. Together with MNRETS the national strategy for hydrofluorocarbon (HFC) phase-out, targeting emission reductions in the cooling sector was developed to implement the Kigali amendment of MOntreal protocol.The UNDP's flagship study, the National Human Development Report, focused on energy poverty, addressing energy accessibility in line with Kyrgyzstan's priorities and international commitments for a just energy transition.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, Kyrgyzstan made significant progress in implementing its Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) commitments and strengthening its climate governance framework. Guided by the overarching goals of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 and advancing gender-responsive and inclusive climate policies, the year was marked by key milestones across legislative, financial, institutional, and technical areas. A gender-responsive NDC Implementation Plan was finalized, providing a comprehensive framework to ensure inclusivity in climate action. This plan incorporates gender-specific measures and focuses on equitable climate policies, ensuring the active participation of women and marginalized groups in sustainable development. it can be served as a basis for the next cycle of NDC 3.0 generation. Efforts to strengthen the legislative and regulatory environment included:Drafting updated legislations and regulations to establish an enabling framework for the Concept of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 and NDC implementation. The new draft of Law on Climate action was prepared by active MPs and MNRETS with support of UNDP by the end of 2024Finalizing the Concept for achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 (LTC) and submitting it to the President's Administration. This submission reflects Kyrgyzstan’s long-term commitment to sustainable, low-carbon, and climate-resilient development.Climate Change coordination mechanisms were supported to facilitate inter-ministerial and multilevel collaboration, promoting a whole-of-government and gender-responsive approach to NDC implementation, green recovery, and long-term climate strategies. To support effective climate action, substantial progress was made in developing financial and economic frameworks:A gender-responsive financial framework for NDC implementation was finalized, incorporating diverse financing sources from international, domestic, and private sectors to support green recovery efforts.A cost-benefit analysis of the gender-responsive NDC Implementation Plan highlighted the economic advantages of sustainable investments.A financing strategy was developed to ensure efficient delivery on National Development Strategy and SDG objectives.An evidence-based assessment demonstrated how low-carbon measures contribute to Kyrgyzstan’s long-term economic development.In addition to achieving these milestones, preliminary work on NDC 3.0 commenced in 2024. This included:Mapping contributions from various UN agencies to align efforts with the Government’s climate priorities.Securing an agreement with the Government on NDC 3.0’s framework, ensuring alignment with national strategies and international climate commitments.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Enhanced human wellbeing, capabilities and equality in Georgia by 2030
Outcome: Outcome 3: By 2025, all people without discrimination benefit from a sustainable, inclusive and resilient economy in Georgia
Output: 3.2. Sustainable and inclusive agricultural and rural development, strengthened food systems and improved livelihoods.
Sub-Output: Focusing on particular value chains, determine the needs of primary producers and Food Business Operators (FBOs), enhance their food safety regulations and standards and provide technical and financial support for better production and improved food security
Description: To increase compliance by producers and food business operators with the new SPS/food safety regulations entering into force through support packages
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: European Union, Swedish International Development Agency
Implementation partners: Czech Development Agency, Ministry of Environmental Protection and Agriculture of Georgia (MEPA)
SDG Targets: 2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.2 3.2. Sustainable and inclusive agricultural and rural development, strengthened food systems and improved livelihoods.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: FAO has completed a thorough training needs assessment for primary producers and FBOs to determine the current level of knowledge and skills on food safety of various stakeholders in Georgian agriculture and identify areas where additional training is required. This assessment includes a review of available data and statistics, as well as primary data collection activities. The results of the assessment were used to guide the development of training programs and initiatives aimed at addressing identified needs and improving overall food safety and quality, and the primary focus of intervention was to provide trainings in the dairy and vegetable value chains for primary producers, FBOs, and input dealers. FAO also worked on the development of technical material for field visits and technical assistance provision to primary producers.In addition, FAO started focus group discussions about the role and implications of women within different value chains. The findings are to be used to further fine tune the training and support to be provided to the target beneficiaries. Support packages on food safety for primary producers and FBOs were conceptualized, which will couple a training to a facilitated access to finance for improved equipment or installations to comply with food safety regulations.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, six training sessions, comprised of 3 targets groups were conducted on Food Safety in the Food Processing Industry for the purpose of facilitating support to FBOs in Georgia. In total, 54 participants from respective FBOs were trained through this support. Also, FAO agriculture extension specialists provided 14 training sessions for local meat processing FBO, and approximately 250 FBO employees were trained. As for providing technical and financial support for better production and improved food security in Georgia, FAO signed a support package with the Georgian Hazelnut Growers Association (GHGA), aiming to promoting food safety at first-level hazelnut buying centers in the Samegrelo and Guria regions. 8 beneficiaries were selected for the establishment of hazelnut buying points. These buying points will be established according to the standards developed by the National Food Agency. It would significantly contribute to the efficient first-level collection and temporary storage of raw materials and enhance their quality, and these centers are operated and managed by private entrepreneurs who acts as intermediaries connecting smallholder farmers and storage and drying facilities. Moreover, the support package coupled a training to a matching grant for improved equipment or installations for beneficiaries to comply with food safety regulations. In total, 2,523 farmers participated in 134 training sessions. The training program empowered hazelnut farmers with knowledge and skills related to food safety, post-harvest management, GAP, and aflatoxin prevention.
2024 Narrative: Private sector competitiveness in agri-food markets was also enhanced through extensive training and capacity-building programs. More than 1,000 staff from Food Business Operators (FBOs), including both management and floor-level employees, received training in Good Hygiene Practices (GHP), Good Storage Practices (GSP), and Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP) to improve food safety standards. In the wine sector, 250 export-oriented companies were trained to strengthen their compliance with international regulations, increasing their readiness for global markets. In parallel, 471 students actively participated in Eco Clubs and public school initiatives focused on sustainable agriculture, while 120 veterinary students attended specialized training sessions in dairy, aquaculture, and beekeeping, fostering the next generation of agri-food professionals.To support farmers in improving productivity and market access, four targeted Support Packages were implemented or are currently in progress, benefiting fish farmers, vegetable producers, and dairy women farmers. As part of these initiatives, 145 beneficiaries received financial and technical assistance for food safety-related investments, enabling them to comply with international standards.A qualitative survey was conducted among agricultural product associations and export professionals to identify key barriers to market access, leading to enhanced trade facilitation efforts. A TRACES NT workshop was attended by 50 technical staff from NFA and Revenue Services, alongside 15 private sector representatives, to streamline export procedures. Additionally, a coordination meeting among agri-food laboratories was held to assess sectoral needs and improve national laboratory capacities for export compliance.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote inclusive and gender transformative approaches to climate action, disaster risk management and environmental protection to conserve natural resources and leverage ecosystem benefits for sustainable human development (CLIMATE, ENERGY, DRM AND BIODIVERSITY)
Outcome: By 2027, the Kyrgyz Republic has started the transition to low-carbon development and risk-informed climate resilience, contributing to people’s fair and equitable access to ecosystem benefits and to empowerment of vulnerable communities in the governance of natural resources and disaster prevention
Output: Critical ecosystems are better protected throughout the country, and the rational and sustainable use of natural resources, including water and land, is improved through gender-responsive, participatory and conflict-sensitive systems at all levels
Sub-Output: Capacity building activities for safeguarding the environment  - mine tailing and water resources
Description:
- Mine tailings safety and the prevention of accidental water pollution The main objectives of the subregional workshop are: to strengthen tailings risk governance; to present recent achievements by Central Asian countries in this area, notably since the last subregional workshop on this topic, held in Almaty, Kazakhstan, in 2019; and to exchange experiences, good practices and lessons learned on the prevention of accidental water pollution from tailings at the regional level.

- Development of joint measures to prevent and respond to pollution of the Syr Darya river in emergencies (Phase i): The overall objective is to reduce and prevent pollution of the water resources of the transboundary Syr Darya river. Currently, the project is in Phase 1 of its implementation, which includes understanding disaster risks and identifying potential sources of accidental pollution (the inventory and hazard/risk map of tailings by the riparian countries is the part of this activity), managing disaster risks and strengthening preparedness for an effective response. 

- Addressing technological/industrial accident risks in national strategies and DRR plans of Kyrgyzstan. Kyrgyzstan is supported with enriching its National DRR strategic documents, incl. its action plan with information on technological/industrial accident risk (within the context of the Industrial Accidents Convention, covering chemical installations as well as tailing management facilities (TMFs)), incl. in relation to Natech and transboundary cooperation).  It aims to set the scene for broader joint cooperation with UNDRR, joining forces in the pursuit of common policy objectives through project-related activities in CA. 

- Conducting an annual meeting of the National Policy Dialogue on water, and develop policy packages upon agreement (laws, studies, etc.). The activities will be done in the frame of the project "Regional mechanisms for the low-carbon, climate-resilient transformation of the energy-water-land Nexus in Central Asia".
Agencies: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe
Contributing partners: Core Funding, United Nations Economic Commission for Europe
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Agriculture, Kyrgyz Ministry of Emergency Situations, Kyrgyz Ministry of Natural Resources, Ecology and Technical Supervision

SDG Goals: 6 Clean Water and Sanitation, 9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure

2023 Narrative: Subregional workshop on mine tailings safety and the prevention of accidental water pollution in Central Asia finalised the development of joint measures to prevent and respond to pollution of the Syr Darya river in emergencies (Phase i) completed. 2. The final meeting of Central Asia Initiative - 15 February 2023 / Almaty, Kazakhstan presented the main results and achievements, of the “Strengthening disaster resilience and accelerating implementation of Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction in Central Asia” initiative: finalized the development of recommendations for improving national disaster risk reduction (DRR) strategies and governance systems ; supported the the establishment of national DRR platforms; support was also provided to all five Central Asian countries in reporting their national progress through the Sendai Framework Monitor; in the the development of the regional DRR strategy for 2022-2030 and the Action Plan for its implementation in 2022-2023. 25-26 May 2023, The Rumi Hotel, 10 Mirzo Tursunzoda St., Dushanbe, Tajikistan; online participants will connect through ZOOMProject completed in February 2023. Results: Inventory and map of 61 TMFs and 133 other hazardous facilities in the Syr Darya River Basin preparedIn-depth report addressing state of water resources, water quality issues and issues related to policies and institutions for water management, industrial safety and prevention of accidental water pollution. It contains concrete recommendations to be implemented by the riparian countries. Infographics and executive summary with key findingsThe final meeting of Central Asia Initiative - 15 February 2023 / Almaty, Kazakhstan. Venue: CESDRR, 73 Amangeldy street, Almaty, Kazakhstan. Presented the main results and achievements, of the “Strengthening disaster resilience and accelerating implementation of Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction in Central Asia” initiative: review and development of recommendations for improving national disaster risk reduction (DRR) strategies and governance systems; the establishment of national DRR platforms; support to all five Central Asian countries in reporting their national progress through the Sendai Framework Monitor; the development of the regional DRR strategy for 2022-2030 and the Action Plan for its implementation in 2022-2023; as well as the organization of the Regional Forums of Heads of National Disaster Management Agencies in 2020, 2021 and 2022.

Description: Conduct activities to support the development of Implementation Plan on Paris Agreement, update the NDC (Nationally Determined Contributions),  and preraption of Fourth National Communication (NC4) and the First Biennial Update Report (BUR1), Development and implementation of  Measurement, Reporting and Verification (MRE) system for Development of the National Adaptation Plan (NAP), on the implementation of Turkmenisstan's obligations under the UNFCCC

2021 Narrative: UNDP assisted the Government to develop the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) for submission to the UNFCCC. UNDP’s collaboration with other international organization and development partners resulted in mobilization of additional 54,000 USD from the UK Embassy in Ashgabat to support the initial phase of developing of the National GHG inventory system aimed at facilitation of the country’s NDC implementation. UNDP continues its collaboration with UNEP as part of UN-2-UN Agreement concluded in 2019 on preparation of the 4th National Communication of Turkmenistan and the first Biennial Report within the framework of the UNFCCC. In preparation of the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) the CO has successfully collaborated with UNICEF in preparation of a chapter on adaptation to climate change
2023 Narrative: Under Sustainable Cities project : During the reporting period Project supported the work on coordinating the implementation of the UNFCCC and the Paris Agreement, including the coordination of preparation of the document of the Fourth National Communication of Turkmenistan on Climate Change, The First Biennial Report. Project also implemented the work on support the development of draft of the new Greenhouse Gas Inventory System in Turkmenistan (2nd phase), as well as the work aimed at supporting implementation of activities within the framework of the adopted Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) of Turkmenistan under the Paris Climate Agreement. Project supported the activities of the Ozone Center of Turkmenistan to fulfill the country's obligations under the Montreal Protocol and the Kigali Amendment thereto.Under NAP project:International and national consultants have partially completed the assignment. Out of four integral parts of the report for updating the adaptation componend of NDC, the first section on macro-climate trends, potential impacts, and vulnerabilities was completed. The assignment is to be implemented through May 2024; implementation progress is on track.The first section of the report on macro-climate trends, potential impacts, and vulnerabilities was elaborated and presented to the stakeholders as part of the dedicated round-table.Project has developed three draft bylaws instead of one. They are as follows: ·        Draft Regulation of the Working Group on International Agreements on Climate Change of the Interagency Commission for Environmental Protection of Turkmenistan·        Draft Regulation of the Working Group on Biodiversity of the Interagency Commission for Environmental Protection of Turkmenistan·        Draft Regulation on the Secretariat of the Interagency Commission for Environmental Protection of Turkmenistan.
2024 Narrative: Sustainable Cities project coordinated the work on development the draft of BUR1 for UNFCCC (finalyzed). Continued the work on preparation the Fourth National Communication of Turkmenistan on CC for UNFCCC. Also conducted the work on developing the 1st Biennial Transparency Report (BTR1), and ongoing the Turkmenistan NDC Stocktaking analysis witht the preparation to NDC 3.0 development. A number of workshops (including on national level) on climate change, energy efficiency, renewable energy use and ecological monitoring were conducted. Under the NAP project /UNDP the following reports, this output aims to establish a coordination mechanism for adaptation planning, a key activity in 2024 was delivering the 6th seminar, last in a series targeting decision-makers across government institutions (March 2024). This seminar focused on raising awareness of climate change impacts across various sectors, such as water and agriculture. By consistently engaging the same cohort of officials, the project cultivated a skilled group of government representatives now equipped to drive climate adaptation policy.With regard to support updating Turkmenistan's NDC adaptation component, three key reports were finalized in 2024, providing an in-depth assessment of vulnerabilities, adaptation goals, and prioritization methods. These were instrumental in structuring the adaptation component of the NDC update and were reviewed with national stakeholders, thereby embedding local insights into the NDC framework.

Description: The key outcome of this activity is that women, men, girls and boys, in territories affected or at risk of being affected by landmines and ERW in conflict-affected areas, enjoy equal access to quality age, gender and disability sensitive services thanks to mine action conducted in accordance with IMAS (safe, efficient and effective MA).
Implementation partners: Donetsk Oblast Civil-Military Administration, Luhansk Oblast Civil-Military Administration
SDG Targets: 16.1 Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.,16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 3 - Sustaining Peace is the principal objective
2021 Narrative: The National Mine Action Centre received essential demining equipment, including large loop detectors, underwater and land mine detectors, diving equipment for demining and other gadgets to conduct demining works in Donetsk and Luhansk oblasts and ensure quality control of the cleared areas. A Gender Handbook for Mine Action Operators has been developed to provide guidelines on gender prioritization in 4 components of mine action: demining, explosive risk awareness, advocacy, and assistance to people suffered from mines. Over 7,000 (48% women) citizens of Donetsk and Luhansk oblasts increased their awareness about possible risk and safer behaviour relating to mines and explosive remnants of war. Moreover, an online platform has been launched to train mine risk education trainers; as of December 2021, 145 people (89 from Donetsk and 56 from Luhansk oblasts) underwent the online learning.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Transparent and accountable democratic governance
Outcome: Outcome 4: Good Governance
Output: Output 4.3 Improved participatory policy making based on better data
Sub-Output: Linking up existing and new opportunities for adolescent participation and empowerment (including through U-report and volunteers), and advocates for a more prominent role of adolescents in society
Description: Support youth entrepreneurship and social innovation through organizing youth challenges and innovation camps.
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
In line with the current initiatives of the country office and the momentum of reform in the education and environment domains, UNICEF launched a joint initiative with the Office of the President of North Macedonia, titled “Reimagine the future”. The initiative commenced with an exploratory phase reaching out to many young people to identify the key areas of their interest and concern. Based on the data gathered with over 700 young people, a series of deep-dive consultations with youth from across the country were held on three distinct topics: Education, Environment and Climate change and Mental health and wellbeing. The recommendations arising from these discussions were incorporated in a Youth for Action Strategy aimed at policy makers. This Youth for Action Strategy was signed and backed by the President of North Macedonia, pledging to champion these calls on their behalf.

As previously reported, North Macedonia participated in the second Generation Unlimited Global Challenge and yet again produced one of the five global finalists. The eBionics team competed with their solution to expand access to prosthetic care with Venus Arm, an open-source 3D printed bionic arm for people with upper limb deficiency. In the months following the announcement of the winners, the team continued their work, this time with a dedicated implementing partner supporting them in following the incubation plan to further advance the idea. An initial pitch is scheduled for September 2021. Another notable success is one of the runners-up in the local competition. Working on the Walkiie application, the team “Something Atypical” received global recognition as one of the seven World Bank 2020 Ideas for Action Winners. The application is designed to connect friends, family, teachers or volunteers with people with disabilities, supporting them to pursue new activities or schedule specific tasks.
2022 Narrative: In 2022 UNICEF managed to scale-up existing opportunities for youth participation and empowerment in their overall reach as well as impact. As a result of UNICEF supported venues and tools, young people in the country co-created three major national policies and strategies including: the National Transforming Education Commitment – as part of the Global Transforming Education Summit, the National Development Strategy 2022-2042, and the National Strategy for Prevention and Justice for Children. Young people were engaged through multiple live debates and consultations as well as through U-Report which has increased its base of U-Reporters threefold in this year alone (200 to 920). By the end of the year U-Report was once again used as the primary channel for youth engagement in co-creating and validating another key document - the new National Youth Strategy. These efforts are consolidating UNICEF’s role as the ‘go to agency’ on youth participation and empowerment, and youth’s input in these key documents ensures that their voice has real, tangible, impact.UNICEF supported programmes also placed young people in the position to develop new skills, innovate and implement solutions to challenges in their communities and the country. A total of 465[1] young people from diverse backgrounds (majority of which were girls) actively participated and developed 94[2] innovations and products through four major programmes: UPSHIFT, Generation Unlimited, Social and Emotional Learning (SEL) and Justice for Children (J4C). In doing so, UNICEF actively supported the engagement of girls in STEM, equipping them with the necessary skills and attitudes for social innovation and entrepreneurship.During the reporting year, the UPSHIFT programme focused on youth-led solutions to environmental challenges in three areas: water, air, and energy. 150 young people participated in these thematic UPSHIFT cycles, implemented in partnership with the Fund for Innovation and Technological Development. Out of the 30 developed solutions, 15 received seed funding and were implemented in communities. Furthermore, for the first time a crowdfunding initiative was implemented by the young people themselves to complement the seed funding. Some of these solutions with minor adaptations have a great potential beyond the country. They are aimed to tackle water usage efficiency, energy conservancy and air pollution.The third Generation unlimited was implemented again in partnership with the Telekom Foundation for Macedonia. Over 127 young people applied with solutions to mitigate climate change effects and 40 of them participated in a three-day workshop to finalize and pitch their ideas. The best 5 solutions received seed funding and two competed in the Global challenge. Some of them include: an application that encourages users to reduce waste and promote a circular economy through swaps and trades; a soil bin for the household that makes best use of organic waste; and a smart trash bin that is sorting waste in preparation for recycling.
2023 Narrative: A youth-led campaign against cyberviolence included 27 young people from across the country in a three-day workshop with mental health experts, and media professionals. The young people developed 20 social media reels and motioned graphic materials that reached more than 62.200 people on social media. Finally, a “Takeover the Assembly” event was organized on World Children’s Day, with 54 young people that took over a Parliament session opening discussion on three topics that they have identified themselves as the most important issues facing children and young people today.Youth participation in policy development through UNICEF supported venues and platforms was also very successful. In 2023 through U-Report and multiple other venues and events young people directly contributed to important legislation and strategies (National Strategy for Prevention and Justice for Children, National Youth Strategy, HPV and vaccination campaigns, Mental health and Violence against Children).

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Prosperity and Planet - Inclusive Economic Growth and Environmental Sustainability
Outcome: Outcome 3.2: By 2025, all people in Kazakhstan, in particular most vulnerable, benefit from increased climate resilience, sustainable management of environment and clean energy, and sustainable rural and urban development.
Output: Output 3.2.2: I Improved capacities of relevant public authorities for development and implementation of Climate and DRR policies in the urban and rural areas, with a focus on vulnerable groups.
Sub-Output: Assistance in Enhancement of Kazakhstan’s Nationally Determined Contributions
Description: The project aims to introduce a modern monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) system and include adaptation measures into the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) of the Republic of Kazakhstan. It is planned to develop a roadmap for implementation of obligations, which will indicate the main directions of national activities for adaptation and reduction of greenhouse gases, and which will provide technical guidance for the Government of Kazakhstan to achieve greenhouse gas emission reduction targets and adaptation measures.
Implementation partners: Ministry of Ecology, Geology and Natural Resources
SDG Targets: 13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.,13.b Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Q1-Q2:
Support is being provided to the Government on updating National Determined Contributions under UNFCCC
